pros: Visible senior management, positive brand and excellent research outputs
cons: None I can comment on for my role

review_title: Toxic culture within the HR department
pros: The physical environment is better than other NHS trusts I've been to
cons: Senior management within HR are very weak, ineffective and toxic. They do not show any accountability for their actions and leave other more junior staff to pick up the pieces for their poor, and often unfair, decision making. I often witnessed a very senior member of the team show disdain and disrespect for others in the wider HR team and employees across GOSH. The culture within HR is extremely toxic. Many colleagues were off sick or left the team due to poor behaviours that were left untackled. Poor performance and bad behaviour is tolerated - there are a number of long standing members of the HR team who should have been managed out years ago. The focus of the HR Director was often on the rest of the organisation to the detriment of not getting the basics right within the HR function. The needs to be a total overhaul of leadership with an emphasis on the right values and behaviours.

review_title: Management need better training, work to be done on culture
pros: CEO seems willing to listen and the hospital had great innovation
cons: Negative culture and discrimination experienced. Spoke to HR, Union, directors and unfortunately no avail.

pros: Friendly Approachable Incredible medical work Excellent reseach
cons: Lacks accountability Slow responses from support services e.g HR, Recruitment, Finance

pros: Great reputation, it was a good opportunity at that time
cons: No leadership, chaos and confusion, hopefully changed since then. I remember a CQC inspection

job_title: Health Play Specialist in London, England
pros: I worked with some amazing colleagues in hospital administration and psychology.
cons: The culture I experienced was one of self-satisfaction and pride, and strong resistance to informed process improvement. Patient and family centered care seemed like a foreign concept to many. It was difficult to advocate to key medical personnel for proper psychosocial care of patients - performed by psychosocial professionals. Care could be better if research were more important than seniority, tradition, and staff preference. We were also grossly understaffed.

job_title: Senior Configuration Analyst in London, England
pros: Excellent work culture here at GOSH
cons: Pay is a bit less as compared to private hospitals

review_title: Not a welcoming place for black people

cons: Lack of individual staff rooms. Lack of diversity

pros: Amazing working environment and great team and working conditions
cons: High demand and pressure love it

pros: Flexible working hours. Exposure to manual methods.
cons: poor training. lots of night shifts.

pros: Lovely place to work great team
cons: Regular senior management changes caused instability.

pros: Met lovely reception admins taff
cons:
Lack of development opportunities, you are thrown in deep end 

Promotions are given to managers' friends and favouritism 

Staff not following policies as they don't know the correct way

Equipment outdated 1 laptop was shared with 6 admins so embarrassing 

Short staffed and overstretched and heavily overworked 

Too many junior staff members with no knowledge, who require training.

Rude surgical and medical team esp nurses and doctors 

Senior management doesn't support staff during escalations, service manager never in or cares, didn't even say hello to new staff member or know anyone's correct name of who is who.  

Line manager constantly wfh Fridays and never replies or picks up phone and does A/L 1 day a week and disappears for few days off sick. Completely useless. 

Zero benefits for the staff.

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in London, England
pros: keeps you busy, some remote working, salary increase per year as per band increase increment? god bless our NHS!
cons: work culture isn't great, micro managed within SD, not much progression unless you seek this. on call isn't the best either.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros: Small department and friendly staff. Great location to work in central London.
cons: Poor executive management team, lack leadership and constantly changing their minds on the priorities of the hospital. Seems to be more of a who you know to get a promotion than what you know for the senior leadership team.

review_title: Poor work life balance and no care for well-being
pros: This is a very large organization with many wonderful people and a great place to be a medical professional. Good opportunities to learn. My comments relate to just pockets of the organization within corporate services
cons: Culture of bullying and unfair treatment mainly by senior management. Failure to protect health and well-being of staff through excessive workload ( they talk the talk but don’t practice it)

pros: State of the art equipment, online systems
cons: From day one my disabilities were ignored and brushed aside even though they were disclosed from the application stage. Was refused support so I burnt out. They tried to fire me during long term sickness but were unsuccessful. This caused a lot of trauma for me, so I found another job elsewhere where I'd be welcomed for who I am.

review_title: Great medical work yet poor management
pros:
Some of the best medical staff you will meet - inspiring. 
Good opportunities to develop if you want to.
cons:
Unprofessional bullying manager who was the reason I left as I couldn't stand my manager's bullying anymore. This member of staff had been reported multiple times and nothing was ever done. Several members of staff left due to this person.
My workload was unrealistic and I ended up doing many tasks that my manager was supposed to be doing. 
Wards understaffed with too high a workload. 
Management do not listen and do not take staff complaints seriously. 
Hostile working atmosphere in the area I worked in.

review_title: Forget public sector especially the NHS
pros: you are in a world class establishment with probably the best minds in the world, if you are into your field this is the place to be.
cons: Lack of funds hinders progression, equipment, staff, so a lot of cost saving can be frustrating when you need equipments for WORK!!! staff to help and management t approve training!

review_title: Engrained culture if bullying and intimidation
pros: Hospital has a good reputation.
cons: Senior staff manage via loosely veiled threats and intimidation. Working unpaid overtime is par for the course. Will overload you with work and make you feel completely incompetent if you struggle to keep up with the unrealistic work load. Most of all they just don’t listen to staff which is just unacceptable when at the end of the day issues staff are raising are often just because they are concerned about giving patients the best quality of care.

pros:
The staff really make the organisation, they’re very supportive and friendly. It’s nice working in an atmosphere where everyone cares so much about the standard of care we deliver. 
The salary is also good in comparison to similar roles at different organisations.
cons: I found admin work to be quite dull but there are plenty of opportunities to move to different areas of the hospital, as well as train and develop.

pros: It is an organisation where you are able to develop yourself and your skills. It is an employer that appreciates the work of its employees and compensates for a job well-done.
cons: A very good pension scheme and opportunity for career development.

pros: Brilliant colleagues, knowing the work you are doing is vital to the health of some of the nation's sickest children.
cons: Underpaid. Undervalued. Staff in management positions have little management training. Slow career progression.

cons: Salary, some nursing staff speak down on you because you’re a student

cons: Management system. Location is in a very expensive part of London.

pros: It is a very good hospital to work in. You can learn alot. Lots of training involved to get you validated.
